hints_html: There is a direct relation between the median and the cumulative function.
hints_latex:

function.
hints_raw: There is a direct relation between the median and the cumulative function.
question: 7 (c)
sols_html:
The median tmed is defined as

\[\begin{aligned} F(t_\text{med}) = \frac12\end{aligned}\]

Since F(t) is given we can easily calculate that

\[\begin{aligned} \frac12 = F(t_\text{med}) = 1-e^{-t_\text{med}/12}, \quad\text{i.e.} \quad e^{-t_\text{med}/12} = \frac12.\end{aligned}\]

After cross multiplying we get \(\displaystyle e^{t_\text{med}/12} = 2.\) Taking the logarithm ln(x) on both sides yields the final answer

\[\begin{aligned} t_\text{med} = 12\ln(2).\end{aligned}\]

Note: From the class notes you may remember that the median waiting time is given by ln(2)/k. Here k=1/12, see part (a), so our calculated answer agrees with the answer we expected.
sols_raw:
The median ''t<sub>med</sub>'' is defined as

:<math> F(t_\text{med}) = \frac12 </math>

Since ''F(t)'' is given we can easily calculate that

:<math> \frac12 = F(t_\text{med}) = 1-e^{-t_\text{med}/12}, \quad \text{i.e.} \quad e^{-t_\text{med}/12} = \frac12. </math>

After cross multiplying we get <math> \displaystyle e^{t_\text{med}/12} = 2. </math> Taking the logarithm ''ln(x)'' on both sides yields the final answer

:<math> t_\text{med} = 12\ln(2). </math>

''Note: From the class notes you may remember that the median waiting time is given by ln(2)/k. Here k=1/12, see part (a), so our calculated answer agrees with the answer we expected.''
statement_html:
The probability that a newly divided cell will divide again before t hours (where t \(\geq\) 0) is given by

\[\begin{aligned} F(t) = 1-e^{-t/12}\end{aligned}\]

(c) What is the median division time?
statement_raw:
The probability that a newly divided cell will divide again '''before''' ''t'' hours (where ''t'' ≥ 0) is given by
:<math> F(t) = 1-e^{-t/12}</math>

(c) What is the median division time?
